text.p: After decades of fighting that scared away elephants, the animals have started to return to Eritrea.
Six elephants have been sighted in Eritrea since 1993, said Hagos Yohannes, head of the wildlife department at Eritrea's ministry of agriculture.

Eritrea, a province of Ethiopia until 1993, fought a three-decade war of independence against Addis Ababa until Marxist ruler Mengistu Haile Mariam was ousted in 1991. The province became independent in 1993.
Hagos said the elephants crossed into Eritrea over the Setit river, which marks the border with Ethiopia.
"We are starting a project to be able to count elephants, study their migratory and feeding habits," he said on Monday.
The Eritrea elephant population is estimated at between 70 and 100.
